title: Quotation of the Day: Silence in G.O.P. — Aides to President See Little Hope
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 9, 2020.
content: “At some point, truth, freedom and democracy have to ascend, and you step aside.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Sciolino
title: Want to Play La Parisienne? Here’s How
description: Philippine Leroy-Beaulieu, a.k.a. Sylvie of “Emily in Paris,” spills the beans on acting the part of a French femme fatale.
content: PARIS — France may have gone back into lockdown last month, but it still has an international ambassador on small screens everywhere thanks to the actress Philippine Leroy-Beaulieu, a.k.a. Sylvie Grateau in the love-to-hate-it Netflix series “Emily in Paris.” As the head of a luxury marketing agency who overdresses, smokes, mocks political correctness and oozes meanness, she is the extreme version of the “Parisienne,” disseminating style and scorn in equal measure.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Nov. 9, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 9, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 9, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Hakeem Jeffries Wants Democrats to Take a Deep Breath
description: The No. 5 House Democrat is running for another term in his post, as he and a new generation of leaders look to a future after Speaker Nancy Pelosi is gone.
content: Most ways you slice it, House Democrats have had a turbulent few days. Swelling expectations that they would grow their majority in last week’s election crashed amid painful losses, and public blame-trading from some of the chamber’s most outspoken progressives and moderates has added a bitter note to President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: British Peer Criticized for Calling Kamala Harris ‘the Indian’
description: Lord Kilclooney, a member of the House of Lords, claimed not to know the vice president-elect’s name when he wrote the offending Twitter post.
content: LONDON — A peer in the House of Lords, Britain’s unelected second chamber of Parliament, drew heavy criticism from lawmakers on Monday for referring on Twitter to Kamala Harris, the United States vice president-elect, simply as “the Indian.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer and Katie Thomas
title: Pfizer’s Covid Vaccine: 11 Things You Need to Know
description: What’s the big deal? Was it part of Operation Warp Speed? When can you get one?
content: As coronavirus cases surge in the United States and elsewhere, with little relief in sight, the world got good news on Monday. Pfizer and its partner, the German company, BioNTech, announced preliminary results that suggested their vaccine was more than 90 percent effective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Mair
title: One Group Is Unreservedly Happy About the Election Results
description: Libertarians are pleased to have likely dodged the bullet of one-party government control.
content: Lots of people on the left and right found reasons to be a little unhappy, or downright miserable, about the election. The Republican Party lost the White House; Democrats have lost ground in the House, and their path to a Senate majority seems very narrow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu and Nate Schweber
title: The Setups for Outdoor Winter Dining Are Lavish. But Are They Safe?
description: New York’s struggling restaurants will try to lure diners with chandeliers and space blankets — and enclosures that health experts worry could increase the virus risk.
content: A Latin fusion restaurant in Queens will serve crispy arepa cups and ropa vieja at an outdoor dining chalet with rustic wood beams and sparkling chandeliers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Affirmative Action Cases May Reach Supreme Court Even Without Trump
description: Private lawsuits, including one about the University of North Carolina’s admissions policies that began in court on Monday, don’t require the support of the federal government.
content: Since President Trump took office, his administration has challenged the right of colleges to use race as a factor in their admissions policies. It has brought a suit against Yale, supported another against Harvard and suggested that elite institutions have been “fostering stereotypes, bitterness and division among the American people” by dividing them into racial groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Cumberbatch Anderson
title: An Apartment Inspired by Its Owners’ Favorite Restaurants
description: For one of his firm’s rare residential projects, Oliver Haslegrave drew inspiration from his clients’ New York haunts.
content: From the outside, the building, a seven-story former garment and textile factory on Bond Street with an ornate cast-iron and terra-cotta facade, looks much as it did in 1895, when it was constructed. Indeed, it met the criteria for architectural significance laid out by New York’s Landmarks Preservation Commission in 2008, when the organization extended the eastern limit of NoHo’s official historic district, in an effort to maintain the 19th-century vernacular of the small pocket of cobblestone streets that runs between Lafayette and the Bowery, and East Fourth and Bond Streets. Once a booming commercial corridor, the district sprung up during the 1890s, its mix of Romanesque, Revival and Classical styles defined by some of the most noted firms of the day. But this particular building’s well-preserved exterior belies what’s inside on its fifth floor. There, one family has created a cozy and distinctly contemporary home that draws inspiration not from the neighborhood’s past — nor from the influential ’70s and ’80s loft conversions of nearby SoHo — but from the owners’ favorite local restaurants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Stars in a Slog: The Premier League Grind Will Only Get Worse
description: Injuries, fatigue and concern are already mounting amid an unforgiving schedule. But for Europe’s top teams, the worst is still to come.
content: MANCHESTER, England — For a moment, it looked as if Jürgen Klopp was taking issue with Pep Guardiola. Klopp, the Liverpool manager, had sought out Guardiola, his Manchester City counterpart, as soon as the final whistle had blown on their teams’ draw on Sunday. Klopp pulled Guardiola in close, and then swept his arm out across the field, gesticulating at two sets of players heaving with exhaustion, his face serious and his brow furrowed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: After a Broken Bone, the Risk of a Second Fracture
description: Far too few patients are referred for treatment that could stave off another costly, debilitating and sometimes deadly fracture.
content: Older adults who break a bone face a serious yet potentially preventable risk of breaking another, often within the next two years. This is especially true for the more than 340,000 people 65 and older who break a hip and the nearly 700,000 who develop a spinal fracture each year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lovia Gyarkye
title: An Artist’s Continuing Exploration of the Human Form
description: Almost 50 years after the debut of her arresting womb-like sculptures, Senga Nengudi is still challenging what it means to live in a body, especially when that body is Black and female.
content: IN 1975, AFTER the birth of her first son, the artist Senga Nengudi began making a series of sculptures with nylon pantyhose, prompted by the physical and psychological changes she experienced during pregnancy. She was in her early 30s, a first-time mother, and fascinated by how her own body had grown and morphed. She wanted to express the human body’s elasticity, how it could expand and contract like her sinuous new material, which she cut, ripped and tied. She’d then fill these amorphous forms with sand, which, she said, gave her sculptures a “kind of sensuality that the body has.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: Buffeted by Trump, China Has Little Hope for Warmer Relations With Biden
description: Many in Beijing believe that the United States will remain hostile to the country’s rise, regardless of who is president.
content: All along China’s leaders publicly professed indifference to the American presidential election, having concluded that no matter who won, the United States would remain irreconcilably opposed to the country’s rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Pfizer releases promising vaccine results.
content: The drugmaker announced the promising development on Monday. Early analysis of a late-stage trial suggested the vaccine was robustly effective in preventing Covid-19. The stock markets soared after the announcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: brio
description: This word has appeared in 28 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle, Lisa Friedman and Coral Davenport
title: Trump Administration Removes Scientist in Charge of Assessing Climate Change
description: Michael Kuperberg was told he would no longer oversee the National Climate Assessment. The job is expected to go to a climate-change skeptic, according to people familiar with the changes.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House has removed the scientist responsible for the National Climate Assessment, the federal government’s premier contribution to climate knowledge and the foundation for regulations to combat global warming, in what critics interpreted as the latest sign that the Trump administration intends to use its remaining months in office to continue impeding climate science and policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Industry’ and ‘Transhood’
description: A new drama follows graduates working in London’s banking world, an HBO documentary follows families raising transgender children, and Reba McEntire and Darius Rucker host the CMA Awards.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 9-15. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nellie Bowles
title: Businesses Trying to Rebound After Unrest Face a Challenge: Not Enough Insurance
description: Some activists have downplayed the damage to businesses from looting and arson in racial justice protests around the country. But some small entrepreneurs are struggling.
content: KENOSHA, Wis. — It’s a prominent refrain these days from activists in the aftermath of arson and looting — businesses have insurance. Buildings can be repaired. Broken glass is a small price to pay in a movement for justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: L.S.U. Player’s Accusations of Police Assault Prompt Investigation
description: Koy Moore said on Twitter that police officers “violated” him “numerous times” Saturday night, leading the Baton Rouge Police Department to place three officers on paid leave amid an investigation.
content: A football player at Louisiana State University said he was “violated numerous times” by police officers last Saturday night, prompting the Baton Rouge Police Department to place three officers involved in the incident on paid leave as it investigates the allegations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas, David Gelles and Carl Zimmer
title: Pfizer’s Early Data Shows Vaccine Is More Than 90% Effective
description: Pfizer announced positive early results from its coronavirus vaccine trial, cementing the lead in a frenzied global race that has unfolded at record-breaking speed.
content: The drug maker Pfizer announced on Monday that an early analysis of its coronavirus vaccine trial suggested the vaccine was robustly effective in preventing Covid-19, a promising development as the world has waited anxiously for any positive news about a pandemic that has killed more than 1.2 million people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The first significant sign that a coronavirus vaccine could actually work.
content: Nine months into the pandemic, we have some potentially game-changing vaccine news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Even as Trump Cut Immigration, Immigrants Transformed U.S.
description: The past four years have seen a steep reduction in immigration. But the country is becoming ever more diverse.
content: GRAND ISLAND, Neb. — To grasp the impact of the latest great wave of immigration to the United States, consider the city of Grand Island, Neb.: More than 60 percent of public school students are nonwhite, and their families collectively speak 55 languages. During drop-off at Starr Elementary on a recent morning, parents bid their children goodbye in Spanish, Somali and Vietnamese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: A House Divided
description: Joe Biden made national unity a central message of his campaign. But the election showed that unity won’t happen overnight.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport
title: Federal Reserve’s Emergency Loan Programs at Center of Political Fight
description: Democrats are eyeing the programs as a backup option if they can’t strike a deal to aid states and localities, and believe they may be needed to backstop markets. Republicans want them off the table.
content: WASHINGTON — A political fight is brewing over whether to extend critical programs that the Federal Reserve rolled out to help keep credit flowing to companies and municipalities amid the pandemic-induced recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis and Niraj Chokshi
title: While the Pandemic Wrecked Some Businesses, Others Did Fine. Even Great.
description: Third-quarter financial results suggest that strong companies have gotten stronger and that some others are in dire straits.
content: The pandemic has turbocharged profits at some big businesses, like Amazon, which reported a 70 percent increase in earnings in the first nine months of the year. But it has devastated others, like Delta Air Lines, which lost $5.4 billion in just the third quarter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: Plan for a Safe Thanksgiving Break
description: Health officials and college administrators are worried about Thanksgiving. We have tips to students and families prepare for an uncertain holiday.
content: Thanksgiving is just over two weeks away. Families, of course, want to be together. But college students, who have watched the virus rip through universities before radiating off campus, may pose a significant risk to their loved ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randall Munroe
title: What Makes Sand Soft?
description: Understanding how grains flow is vital for everything from landslide prediction to agricultural processing, and scientists aren’t very good at it.
content: What is the softest sand in the world? Why is some sand softer than others?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: 71 Million People Voted for Trump. They’re Not Going Anywhere.
description: We are still a nation painfully divided.
content: NASHVILLE — For at least a week before Election Day, I was too anxious to focus. Donald Trump was running a re-election campaign founded in lies, and I had no faith that my fellow Americans would throw him out. The polls were reassuring, but I wasn’t reassured. Polls were reassuring in 2016, too, and this country still ended up in an abusive relationship with the most corrupt and dangerous president of my lifetime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Alexander Hamilton, Enslaver? New Research Says Yes
description: A paper by a researcher at the Schuyler Mansion finds overlooked evidence in letters and Hamilton’s own account books indicating that he bought, sold and personally owned slaves.
content: The question has lingered around the edges of the pop-culture ascendancy of Alexander Hamilton: Did the 10-dollar founding father, celebrated in the musical “Hamilton” as a “revolutionary manumission abolitionist,” actually own slaves?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘Fargo’ Season 4, Episode 8 Recap: Best Laid Plans
description: Loy’s strategy to turn brother against brother hits a snag. But so do just about everyone else’s schemes this week.
content: It’s probably unfair to chide “Fargo” for ripping off a major set-piece from Brian De Palma’s “The Untouchables” since De Palma himself has been knocked for ripping off Alfred Hitchcock. And the set-piece in question, a shootout at Chicago’s Union Station, nods to the famed Odessa Steps sequence in Sergei Eisenstein’s “Battleship Potemkin.” Nevertheless, the quotes around quotes around quotes somewhat diminish the impact of a show that can seem, at times, like a shallow pastiche without the undergirding of original ideas or thematic purposefulness. Its pleasures are mostly on the surface.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Why Did the World’s Fastest Man Miss Drug Tests — and a Shot at the Olympics?
description: Christian Coleman was poised for a major breakout at the Tokyo Games this summer, but he was suspended for two years for missing drug tests. How did that happen?
content: Every great athlete makes mistakes and has weaknesses, even the world’s fastest man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Trump’s Defeat Weakens Boris Johnson in Urgent Brexit Talks
description: As the European Union knows, the British prime minister can ill afford to threaten peace in Ireland, an issue close to the President-elect Biden’s heart.
content: LONDON — Few world leaders have felt the fallout of President-elect Joe Biden’s victory more quickly than Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: How New York Reacted to Biden’s Win
description: In heavily Democratic New York City, Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory over President Trump  predictably drew jubilation.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Saw Nang
title: Strong Turnout in Myanmar Shows Voters’ Support for Nascent Democracy
description: Despite defections, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi’s party is expected to remain the strongest force in the Parliament. The military, which ruled for 50 years, still controls much of the government.
content: Lining up for hours on dusty city streets and country dirt lanes, voters in Myanmar turned out en masse on Sunday in elections that were expected to leave the governing party of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi as the biggest force in the country’s Parliament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba
title: Top 10 Misinformation Storylines on Election Week
description: Many of the false and misleading accusations spiked online after President Trump and his allies shared the claims on social media.
content: Election week was a misinformation event of Super Bowl-size proportions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Adam Nagourney
title: An Early Test for Biden: Managing a Divided Democratic Party
description: Moderates and progressives were mostly united during the campaign. Their deep differences will now present a significant challenge for the president-elect.
content: Ever since President Trump won the White House in 2016, a shocked Democratic Party had been united behind the mission of defeating him. Four years later, with the election of Joseph R. Biden Jr., the divides that have long simmered among Democrats are now beginning to burst into the open, as the president-elect confronts deep generational and ideological differences among congressional lawmakers, activists and the party’s grass-roots base.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: When Will Joe Biden Be Sworn In?
description: A bipartisan congressional committee is planning an “outside, full-scale” inauguration ceremony on Jan. 20.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. is expected to be sworn in as the 46th president of the United States on Jan. 20 at an outdoor inauguration ceremony, though the coronavirus pandemic might cause the plans to be scaled back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Jeanna Smialek, Ana Swanson and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden has economic levers to pull even without the Senate.
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will take office in January with a weak economy weighed down by the coronavirus pandemic, millions of Americans still unemployed and businesses struggling and closing as winter bears down.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will take office in January with a weak economy weighed down by the coronavirus pandemic, millions of Americans still unemployed and businesses struggling and closing as winter bears down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Monika Pronczuk
title: Europe to Impose Tariffs in 16-Year Trade Fight With U.S.
description: U.S. aircraft, frozen orange juice and handbags will cost more, in an escalation of the Boeing-Airbus subsidy battle.
content: PARIS — The European Union said Monday that it would begin imposing sweeping tariffs on around $4 billion worth of American aircraft, food, drinks and other products beginning Tuesday, an action cleared by the World Trade Organization last month after it said Europe could retaliate against the United States for years of illegal subsidies given to Boeing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Dan Camp, Who Created a Mississippi Jewel, Dies at 79
description: He developed the trendy Cotton District from a run-down area next to Mississippi State, anticipating the New Urbanism movement. He died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Frances Robles
title: Tropical Storm Eta Causes Flooding in South Florida
description: Some areas saw more than 13 inches of rainfall, and there was a storm surge along the coast.
content: MIAMI — South Florida awoke to streets turned into shallow rivers on Monday after Tropical Storm Eta soaked the region overnight. It dumped rain inland, caused storm surge along the coast and left hundreds of thousands of people without electricity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nik Sharma
title: The Crunchiest, Creamiest, Tangiest Brussels Sprouts
description: The unfairly maligned vegetable gets an update with creamy labneh and irresistible pickled shallots.
content: Brussels sprouts are among the most traditional ingredients on the Thanksgiving table, and, when roasted, this unfairly maligned brassica shines brilliantly among the various sides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas St. Fleur
title: How a Human Cousin Adapted to a Changing Climate
description: A skull found in a South African cave suggests that the species went through a process of microevolution during a chaotic environmental shift.
content: On Father’s Day in June 2018, Samantha Good was working on an excavation in the Drimolen cave in South Africa’s Cradle of Humankind. She uncovered what appeared to be a canine tooth jutting out from the loose brown sediment. Ms. Good kept digging until she found two more teeth and a partial palate, and then alerted her instructors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: Biden’s Win Means a Demotion for Netanyahu and Less Focus on Israel
description: Benjamin Netanyahu has made his closeness to President Trump, who gave him much of what he wanted, central to his political appeal. Things will be different in a Biden administration.
content: JERUSALEM — President Trump’s defeat has left Israel and its longtime prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, on the receiving end of an abrupt demotion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Precious Achiuwa’s Journey May Finally Take Him to the N.B.A.
description: Achiuwa has gone from Nigeria to New York to Memphis, cultivating an “extreme level of versatility” in his game that is key to making it in today’s N.B.A.
content: Precious Achiuwa has never been in the same place for long. He tends to be on the move — from Nigeria to New York to Memphis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Ariana Grande Streams Her Way to a Fifth No. 1 With ‘Positions’
description: The singer’s latest album opened with nearly 174 million streams, the most by a woman since Taylor Swift’s “Folklore” debuted in July.
content: Ariana Grande takes the top spot on the Billboard album chart for a fifth time with her latest release, “Positions,” cementing her role as one of the queens of streaming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: N.Y.P.D. Will No Longer Force Women to Remove Hijabs for Mug Shots
description: The Police Department agreed to change its policy and allow religious people to be photographed in head coverings so long as their faces were left unobstructed.
content: Two years ago, two Muslim women joined forces to sue the New York Police Department, claiming they had suffered the same embarrassing ordeal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Our 6th Annual Student Review Contest
description: We invite middle school and high school students to play critic and submit an original review about any kind of creative expression covered in The Times. Contest open from Dec. 8, 2020 to Jan. 26, 2021.
content: Do you like sharing your opinion with others? Do you have strong critiques and reactions to books, movies, restaurants or fashion? Are you a foodie or a gamer?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: Helping Children With Anxiety in the Pandemic
description: Even in an anxious time, children’s anxiety is treatable.
content: Yes, this is an anxious time, and yes, everyone is anxious, but it is particularly hard to be an anxious kid in an anxious time. Anxiety disorders are the most common mental health disorders in children and adolescents (and this was true before the pandemic), and they can be linked to other mental health issues, notably depression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.7 Million Homes in California
description: An Edwardian home in San Francisco, a Spanish-style house in San Diego and a three-bedroom beachside condominium in Malibu.
content: This house is in Bernal Heights, a mostly residential area south of the San Francisco Mission District. The neighborhood’s main drag, Cortland Avenue, is home to small grocers, bakeries and restaurants, including a French bistro and a Nepalese cafe. A block north of the house is Bernal Heights Park, one of the largest green spaces in the city, with views of San Francisco Bay and the skyline. Noe Valley is about 10 minutes away by car; the financial district is a 15-minute drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne and Michael Gonchar
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Biden Wins Presidency, Ending Four Tumultuous Years Under Trump’
description: In this lesson, students consider what the Biden-Harris victory means for the United States.
content: Featured Article: “Biden Wins Presidency, Ending Four Tumultuous Years Under Trump” by Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Trump Lost the Race. But Republicans Know It’s Still His Party.
description: Inside the Zoom salons, Senate-office conversations and 2024 jockeying that will shape the future of the G.O.P.
content: The election of 2020 ended for Republican Party leaders a lot like the election of 2016 began: As much as they may want to move on from Donald J. Trump, he won’t let them — and neither will the voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter and Katrin Bennhold
title: The Politics of Terrorism in a Combustible Europe
description: Austria and France both suffered deadly attacks in recent weeks. The responses offer a glimpse of the political shape-shifting around Europe’s complex relationship with Islam.
content: PARIS — October’s knife slayings by freelance terrorists shocked the French but have not led to the global outpouring of sympathy for France seen after Islamist massacres in 2015 and 2016. European leaders have expressed solidarity, but the Muslim world has been convulsed with anti-French demonstrations and calls for a boycott.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By María Silvia Trigo and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Evo Morales Returns to Bolivia to Cheers — and Worries
description: Supporters rushed to welcome the divisive former president back from exile, and his party is back in power. But the country’s new leaders have kept their distance.
content: SANTA CRUZ, Bolivia — Bolivia’s maverick former president, Evo Morales, made a triumphant return to his homeland Monday, a year after his failed attempt to keep power tore the nation apart and sent him into exile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Business Leaders, Drawn Into Fray by Trump, See Chance to Step Back
description: Since President Trump took office, corporate America has been thrust into the culture wars like never before. The atmosphere would probably be different with a Biden administration.
content: From the moment President Trump took office, big businesses were thrust into the culture wars like never before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Tom Brady and the Buccaneers Were Blown Out. Was It an Antonio Brown Curse?
description: Brown, the star receiver with a checkered past on and off the field, made his debut with the Buccaneers amid questions around his comeback.
content: The matchup had been anticipated all season: Tom Brady and Drew Brees, two sure-shot Hall of Fame quarterbacks nearing the ends of their careers, facing off in prime time on Sunday. The fact that their teams, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the New Orleans Saints, are battling for control of the N.F.C. South only raised the stakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Third Term of the Obama Presidency
description: Joe Biden represents a move back to normalcy, but progressives will push for change.
content: Barack Obama — his policies and his posture — just won a third term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Should C.E.O.s Keep Speaking Out?
description: They were increasingly outspoken in the Trump era. They may not be when Biden takes over.
content: On Nov. 17-18, DealBook is holding our first Online Summit. Join us as we welcome the most consequential newsmakers in business, policy and culture to explore the pivotal questions of the moment — and the future. Watch for free from anywhere in the world. Register now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: ‘Readymade Cabaret 2.0’ Brings Randomness to Virtual Theater
description: With nods to Duchamp and Dada, this interactive production raises questions about fate, narrative convention and the process of making art.
content: Theatergoers don’t often get to boss performers around. I’ll be frank: It’s fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: France and Italy report record cases as virus ravages Europe.
description: As winter approaches, Europe is struggling with a brutal resurgence of the virus, one that, along with the U.S. surge, has helped push the global case count over 50 million, according to a New York Times database. France and Italy have reported record daily case totals in recent days as both countries have moved to lock down some regions.
content: As winter approaches, Europe is struggling with a brutal resurgence of the virus, one that, along with the U.S. surge, has helped push the global case count over 50 million, according to a New York Times database. France and Italy have reported record daily case totals in recent days as both countries have moved to lock down some regions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur
title: Apple Puts Key Contractor on Probation Over Labor Abuses in China
description: The technology giant said it had suspended future business with the iPhone assembler Pegatron pending corrective actions. The Taiwanese manufacturer broke rules limiting student employee work hours.
content: Apple said on Monday that it had placed a key assembler of its iPhones on probation after the Taiwanese company was found to have concealed violations of labor rules for students employed at its factories in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Chee and Nick Ballón
title: A Haunting Tale of Spies and Specters
description: In this short story written exclusively for T, the ghost of a former North Korean diplomat finds his way back to Leipzig, Germany, and to the woman he once loved.
content: Ghost stories aren’t necessarily meant to frighten — often, they’re ways to explain to ourselves the living’s unresolved matters of the heart: old ambitions, old loves, old hatreds. T’s Nov. 15 Travel issue is dedicated to such tales, including three original short stories written exclusively for the magazine. Below is “Did You Die at Home?” by Alexander Chee. Read more in our letter from the editor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: What Biden’s Win Could Mean for New York: 5 Takeaways
description: A Biden presidency could bring more recovery funds to the city and boost plans to build a new rail tunnel under the Hudson River.
content: Leaders in New York City have been counting on one thing to help the city recover from the pandemic: a Joseph R. Biden Jr. presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Hell Hath No Fury Like a Trump Scorned
description: The victory of the Biden-Harris ticket and the enduring power of Republicanism tell two stories.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, when Joe Biden finally got to give his postelection speech on Saturday night, he reached out to Trump voters who were disappointed about the results. Very typical for Biden, and given the fact that his opponent was sulking in silence — except for a few angry tweets — it did set a heck of a new tone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Biden Bump
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: If Democrats had nominated any candidate other than Joe Biden, President Trump may well have won re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: How Democrats Missed Trump’s Appeal to Latino Voters
description: The election was a referendum on Trump’s America, but plenty of Latino voters liked it just fine.
content: PHOENIX — Democrats thought it would be enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Azerbaijan Apologizes for Downing Russian Helicopter, Killing Two
description: The missile attack on a Russian military helicopter caused the first acknowledged deaths for neighboring powers in the war between Armenia and Azerbaijan.
content: TVER, Russia — Azerbaijan’s foreign ministry apologized on Monday for what it said was the accidental shooting down of a Russian military helicopter, killing two crew members in an incident that threatened to draw Russia more deeply into an already escalating war between Armenia and Azerbaijan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Trump’s Fury Feeds Moscow and Beijing Accounts of U.S. Chaos
description: President Trump’s baseless claims of a stolen election resonate on Russian state media. Both Russia and China have painted American democracy as volatile and vulnerable.
content: MOSCOW — For years, state propaganda in both Russia and China has painted Western democracy as dangerously chaotic compared to what it described as the safety and stability of the countries’ authoritarian systems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Yu
title: Jonathan Lethem Imagines a World Where Technology Stops Working
description: In Lethem’s new novel, “The Arrest,” a visitor upends the pastoral, postapocalyptic lives of a farming community in Maine.
content: THE ARRESTBy Jonathan Lethem
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Mink and the Coronavirus: What We Know
description: Mink are the only animal known to both catch the virus from people and transmit it to them.
content: Last week, Denmark announced its intention to cull all farmed mink, some 17 million, out of fear that a mutated version of the coronavirus might diminish the effectiveness of potential vaccines. The decision has caused dismay in other countries and a debate among scientists about the validity of the concern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Herrera
title: How to Worry Better
description: Make time for it.
content: So, uh … how ya feeling? 🥺
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Garsten
title: How to Protect America From the Next Donald Trump
description: The Constitution is supposed to protect us from demagogues. Can we make it work again?
content: Voting Donald Trump out of office was crucial, but it will not be enough to save the American experiment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Russia waits for court challenges to resolve before addressing the winner of last week’s election.
description: For years, the Kremlin has painted Western democracy as dangerously chaotic compared to what it says is the safety and stability offered by President Vladimir V. Putin. Thanks to President Trump’s unfounded allegations that Democrats stole last week’s presidential election, the Kremlin now has a fresh chance to claim vindication.
content: For years, the Kremlin has painted Western democracy as dangerously chaotic compared to what it says is the safety and stability offered by President Vladimir V. Putin. Thanks to President Trump’s unfounded allegations that Democrats stole last week’s presidential election, the Kremlin now has a fresh chance to claim vindication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Paul Shanley, Ex-Priest in Child Sex-Abuse Scandal, Dies at 89
description: A former counselor for gay and troubled youths, he became a sexual predator and a central figure in a crisis that engulfed the Boston Archdiocese.
content: WARE, Mass. — Paul R. Shanley, a former priest who figured prominently in the child sexual abuse scandal in Boston in the early 2000s that rocked the Roman Catholic Church, has died at 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Thanksgiving Will Soon Empty Campuses. Will Students Bring Coronavirus Home?
description: Experts worry that some of the hundreds of thousands of departing students will be “little ticking time bombs.”
content: As Thanksgiving approaches, millions of Americans are weighing the risk of pandemic travel against the yearning to visit friends and family. But one group seems all but certain to be heading home in large numbers just in time for turkey and holiday gatherings: college students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerry Garrett
title: For NASCAR, a Season of Change
description: To race during the pandemic, practices were eliminated and crews were limited. And the organization made a significant move by banning the Confederate flag from its properties.
content: With Chase Elliott winning the season finale on Sunday at Phoenix Raceway and becoming the champion of the Cup Series, NASCAR allowed itself a moment of congratulations for completing its most challenging year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘The Power of Adrienne Rich’ Captures a Forceful and Complicated Poet
description: Hilary Holladay’s biography examines the upbringing, poems, and political and sexual awakenings of the vital and influential writer.
content: Long before I read her, I disliked Adrienne Rich. It was received opinion. When I was in high school, the people I respected (English teachers, good ones, and fellow bookstore employees, male and female), rolled their eyes at the mention of her name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Where Do We Go From Here?
description: We’ve been asking you questions about the candidates, the electoral process and our democracy for months. Now we’d like to hear about your hopes for the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ari L. Goldman
title: Jonathan Sacks, the U.K.’s Inclusive Former Chief Rabbi, Dies at 72
description: In writings and media appearances, he took a universalist view of religion in a multicultural world — a stance that could get him in hot water with conservatives.
content: Jonathan Sacks, the former chief rabbi of the United Kingdom who emerged as an important and widely heard voice on the role of religion in the modern world, died on Saturday in London. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Saudi Arabia’s leaders congratulate Biden, saying they want to deepen relations with the U.S.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The king and crown prince of Saudi Arabia have each sent cables congratulating President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on his electoral victory, an initial effort by Saudi leaders, who have benefited from a strong relationship with President Trump, to build ties with the new American administration.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The king and crown prince of Saudi Arabia have each sent cables congratulating President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on his electoral victory, an initial effort by Saudi leaders, who have benefited from a strong relationship with President Trump, to build ties with the new American administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Fires Mark Esper, Defense Secretary Who Opposed Use of Troops on U.S. Streets
description: Mr. Esper’s removal was quickly followed by speculation that the president was not finished: The F.B.I. director and the C.I.A. director could be next, according to administration officials.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump fired Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper on Monday, upending the military’s leadership at a time when Mr. Trump’s refusal to concede the election has created a rocky and potentially precarious transition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Booth at a Fair
description: Robert Fisher puts his puzzle to work.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Robert Fisher, he was figuring out alternative ways to say things, and today he is back with a series of occupations that are described in punny ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric A. Taub
title: A Step Forward in the Promise of Ultrafast ‘Hyperloops’
description: Two employees of Virgin Hyperloop traveled on a small system the company has built near Las Vegas, the first such manned test.
content: MOAPA, Nev. — Hyperloop technology, which promises to transport people and goods at speeds of up to 600 miles an hour, has long seemed too good to be true. But one company says it has cleared an important step toward commercializing it by moving two of its employees through a test system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Trump Put Down Philadelphia. The City Got Payback.
description: A city that “will long remember slights,” as one area congressman put it, came through for Joe Biden, who benefited from his ties there and President Trump’s affronts to its voters.
content: PHILADELPHIA — It was just before noon on Saturday, and Bob Brady was trying to reach Joseph R. Biden Jr. on the phone. Mr. Brady, the chairman of the Philadelphia Democrats, wanted to pass along an increasingly open secret among elections officials and the news media: The city was about to release a tally of roughly 3,000 more votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh, Mitch Smith and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: A ‘Terrifying’ Coronavirus Surge Will Land in Biden’s Lap
description: Total coronavirus cases in the U.S. surpassed 10 million on Sunday. Experts say the virus is spreading out of control and could grow worse before President-elect Biden takes office.
content: PITTSBURGH — Hours after President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. declared the coronavirus a top priority, the magnitude of his task became starkly clear on Sunday as the nation surpassed 10 million cases and sank deeper into the grip of what could become the worst chapter of the pandemic yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and John Koblin
title: Helping to Shape the Words of the President-Elect: A Presidential Historian
description: Jon Meacham, best known for writing about past presidents like Andrew Jackson and George Bush, has helped shape some of Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s most significant speeches.
content: WASHINGTON — Jon Meacham, the presidential historian and biographer best known for studying the lives of past presidents, has taken on a relatively unique role in a contemporary political moment: helping to write speeches for the next president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Bryson DeChambeau’s Golf Revolution Turns Toward the Masters
description: DeChambeau aims to conquer genteel Augusta National with brute force. Given his play since bulking up over the past year, lots of golfers — and bettors — think he can.
content: Asked about his childhood as he stood on the practice range at a golf tournament in Connecticut this summer, Bryson DeChambeau said his overriding memory was a conviction that a nonconformist would eventually get more done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May and Amy Chang Chien
title: ‘Stand by Her’: In China, a Movement Hands Out Free Sanitary Pads in Schools
description: Students and teachers are placing pads outside bathrooms as part of a grass-roots campaign to fight period poverty and to remove the stigma surrounding menstruation.
content: HONG KONG — It started when a single box of free sanitary pads appeared in a middle school classroom in October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Sterling Brown Agrees to $750,000 Settlement in Lawsuit Against Milwaukee
description: The city would also have to admit wrongdoing in its arrest of the Milwaukee Bucks player, who sued the city after the police used a Taser to subdue him during a confrontation over a parking violation in 2018.
content: The Milwaukee Bucks player Sterling Brown has reached a tentative agreement under which he would receive $750,000 to settle a lawsuit that he filed against the city in 2018, after the police used a Taser to subdue and arrest him in a confrontation over a parking violation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: Indians Love Cadbury Chocolate. These Rivals Would Love to Woo Them Away.
description: In India and its diaspora, a new array of small companies are using Diwali and its tradition of giving sweets to popularize a different kind of bar.
content: In India, few foreign confections have been more eagerly embraced than chocolate — and no brand defines this affinity more than Cadbury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Cheri Bustos, who leads House Democrats’ campaign arm, says she won’t seek another term as chairwoman.
description: Representative Cheri Bustos of Illinois, the leader of the House Democrats’ campaign arm, told colleagues on Monday that she would not seek another term as chairwoman after she led her party to unexpected losses last week and only narrowly won her own re-election race.
content: Representative Cheri Bustos of Illinois, the leader of the House Democrats’ campaign arm, told colleagues on Monday that she would not seek another term as chairwoman after she led her party to unexpected losses last week and only narrowly won her own re-election race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Rachel Abrams and David Enrich
title: Growing Discomfort at Law Firms Representing Trump in Election Lawsuits
description: Some lawyers at Jones Day and Porter Wright, which have filed suits about the 2020 vote, said they were worried about undermining the electoral system.
content: Like many big law firms, Jones Day, whose roots go back to Cleveland in the late 1800s, has prided itself on representing controversial clients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein and Dana Rubinstein
title: N.Y.C. Dangerously Close to Second Wave, Mayor Says, as New Rules Loom
description: The spike in virus cases threatens the city’s recovery and could mean “a lot more restrictions,” Mayor Bill de Blasio said.
content: As coronavirus cases surged to record highs across the country, New York City had hoped to keep the outbreak at bay and press ahead with its slow but steady recovery from the dark days of spring. But now, the forecast is turning more alarming.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Celebration and Sorrow: Americans React to the Election
description: We traveled the country to capture dispatches from a divided nation.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: Moving to New York to Start Their Dance Careers
description: Two recent college grads are working — and dancing — from their new Brooklyn home during the pandemic.
content: The normal deluge of recent college graduates moving to New York in the late spring and early summer slowed to a trickle this year. Between broad work-from-home policies and employers reluctant to extend job offers, many new grads elected to stay in the childhood homes they had moved back to in March, when college campuses shut down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Roger Ryman, a ‘Real-Life’ Cowboy From Nebraska, Dies at 70
description: After working summers at the family ranch, he decided to saddle up as a job, turning to selling real estate later in life. He died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: The End of ‘America First’: How Biden Says He Will Re-engage With the World
description: Those who have known President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. for decades say they expect him to move carefully, providing reassurance with a few big symbolic acts.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. makes no secret of the speed with which he plans to bury “America First” as a guiding principle of the nation’s foreign policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: This Is the Best Poundcake
description: Keith Lee, a son of Otis Lee, who ran Mr. Fofo’s Deli in Detroit, shared his father’s famous recipe. Make it soon.
content: Good morning. Our CC Allen traveled to Detroit recently to speak with Keith Lee, a son of the restaurateur Otis Lee, who died in April, a victim of the coronavirus. For more than three decades, Otis Lee ran Mr. Fofo’s Deli in the city’s Midtown, famed for its huge corned beef sandwiches and lemon-glazed poundcake (above). Keith Lee recreated his father’s poundcake recipe for CC’s camera, and the resulting video is both affecting and instructive. I hope you’ll watch it and then make the cake. Me, I’ll double the glaze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard McGregor
title: Xi Jinping’s Strength is China’s Weakness
description: Unlike any other Chinese leader since 1949, he has no identifiable rivals and no likely successors.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — President Xi Jinping has accumulated legions of powerful critics in China since he took office in early 2013. There are the once-powerful officials who have been felled by his sweeping anti-corruption campaign. There are the economists who resist his statist instincts. There are the academics who have objected to his authoritarian measures, such as his decision to abolish presidential term limits.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Post-Election Therapy With Esther Perel
description: The couples counsellor has some advice for how to heal “the screaming match” in a relationship — and in our nation.
content: We finally have a President-Elect. But in the midst of a divisive election, an economy in a tailspin and a global pandemic, we could all still use a little healing. Enter Esther Perel, an author and psychotherapist with the power to help mend relationships. “We have a screaming match,” she says, “but we have a foundation underneath that.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: The Election Is Over. The Nation’s Rifts Remain.
description: Joe Biden’s supporters were dancing in the streets. But only half the nation was celebrating, and the nation’s divisions remain on stark display.
content: MAPLEWOOD, N.J. — A late-morning stillness had settled over a November Saturday in a cozy blanket of suburban serenity. Suddenly, at stadium-level blast, there came the shattering rock ’n’ roll roar of victory:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘A Teacher’ Review: After School, Not So Special
description: Kate Mara and Nick Robinson play a teacher and student in a dangerous relationship in this FX on Hulu mini-series.
content: Each of the 10 compact episodes of “A Teacher” begins with an arresting trigger warning: The series contains “depictions of grooming” that may be disturbing. You have to look fast to see them, though. Before the first episode is over, Claire Wilson (Kate Mara), a young English teacher at a Texas high school, is lying to her husband about her SAT tutoring sessions at a local diner with a hunky 18-year-old student, Eric Walker (Nick Robinson). It’s not much longer before the tutoring moves to the back seat of her car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: The Trump Presidency Is Ending. So Is Maggie Haberman’s Wild Ride.
description: For the last four years, the Times reporter has been the human incarnation of a nation riveted, like it or not, by Donald Trump.
content: Maggie Haberman lives rent-free in Donald Trump’s head, all over the front page of The New York Times and also in a brick house in an unglamorous Brooklyn neighborhood out beyond the Citi Bikes and stately brownstones. On election night, as the votes started coming in, she was seated at her dining room table with her husband and one of her three children, drinking from a liter bottle of Foodtown raspberry seltzer, eating leftover Kit Kats from Halloween, typing and texting, and, still, still, working her sources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Navajo Nation, on a weekend lockdown, is experiencing a spike.
description: The Navajo Nation, under a weekend lockdown, is averaging more than 100 new daily cases for the first time since early June.
content: The Navajo Nation, under a weekend lockdown, is averaging more than 100 new daily cases for the first time since early June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Joe Biden, Coronavirus, Europe: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: U.A.E. Changes Laws to Attract Foreign Tourists and Investment
description: The United Arab Emirates is abolishing lenient sentences for so-called honor killings, loosening alcohol restrictions and lessening the sway of Islamic law over foreigners.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The United Arab Emirates announced a series of legal changes over the weekend that improved protections for women, loosened regulations on alcohol consumption and expanded the ability of noncitizens to follow foreign laws for inheritance and divorce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Trading Blame and Worry, Notre Dame Grapples With Celebration’s Fallout
description: The university’s president promised strict punishments for students who break virus protocols. But his credibility on campus is wearing thin.
content: As soon as the final whistle blew, signaling that last-gasp laterals would not prevent the Notre Dame football team from its biggest win in a generation — a 47-40 double-overtime defeat of top-ranked Clemson on Saturday night — a can’t-look-away scene unfolded at Notre Dame Stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Shot to Prevent H.I.V. Works Better Than Daily Pill in Women
description: Researchers ended a clinical trial of the drug early because the results were so convincing. The more effective drug would be given in six injections a year instead of as 365 daily pills.
content: A single shot given every two months has proved to be more effective than a daily pill at preventing H.I.V. in women, researchers reported on Monday, an advance that medical experts hailed as groundbreaking in the fight against the deadly virus that causes AIDS.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian Friedman
title: ‘Lawn and Order!’ ‘Make America rake again.’ The (other) Four Seasons is selling merchandise.
description: What do you do when your local business is thrust into the spotlight as the improbable stage for a political campaign’s news conference challenging the outcome of the presidential election?
content: What do you do when your local business is thrust into the spotlight as the improbable stage for a political campaign’s news conference challenging the outcome of the presidential election?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Tried a More Aggressive Cyberstrategy, and the Feared Attacks Never Came
description: The 2020 election was the biggest test yet of a new approach of pre-emptive action against adversaries trying to hack election infrastructure or wage disinformation campaigns.
content: From its sprawling new war room inside Fort Meade, not far from Baltimore-Washington International Airport in Maryland, United States Cyber Command dived deep into Russian and Iranian networks in the months before the election, temporarily paralyzing some and knocking ransomware tools offline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrea DiCenzo
title: From Iraq, an Intimate Glimpse of the Religious Holiday of Arbaeen
description: Every year, millions of pilgrims descend on the central Iraqi city of Karbala to commemorate the Shiite holiday of Arbaeen, one of the largest organized gatherings in the world.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Andrea DiCenzo shares a collection of images from central Iraq, taken in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: A Collective Sigh of Relief Pushes the Stock Market Up
description: News of Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine progress, and Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory, gave investors reason to cheer.
content: Nothing drags down a market like uncertainty. So on Monday, as clarity emerged around two of the year’s most pressing concerns — the presidential election and the coronavirus — investors let out the equivalent of a street cheer and rushed to buy stocks, placing bullish bets on a return to normalcy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: Dave Grohl, 10-Year-Old Nandi Bushell and One Very Epic Drum Battle
description: The Foo Fighters leader and the English prodigy struck up a competitive friendship on social media that has brought them, and thousands of music fans, immense joy.
content: You didn’t need to know every note of Nirvana’s angst-rock classic “In Bloom” to marvel at the spectacle of a little girl drumming along to the song in perfect synchronization last November, her face scrawled over with joy and passion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Even With a New President, Sports at the White House Won’t Be the Same
description: The politicization of the ceremonial visit to the Rose Garden by champions is one sign the presidential connection to sports is fraught, maybe inalterably.
content: Awe and tension filled the air on that sunny afternoon in the Rose Garden four years ago this week. I could feel it, and so could everyone else on hand: The sense of celebration mixed with a gnawing worry for the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Old Dogs, New Research and the Secrets of Aging
description: The ways that dogs grow and age may provide potentially useful similarities with people.
content: Dogs go through stages in their life, just as people do, as is obvious to anyone who has watched their stiff-legged, white-muzzled companion rouse themselves to go for one more walk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Krysten Chambrot
title: 12 Thanksgiving Desserts Worth Saving Room For
description: Here’s what you need to make the end of the meal shine.
content: A creamy pumpkin pie is a tried-and-true way to end the Thanksgiving meal. You can, of course, stick to tradition, with a classic take. Or … you could live a little. This Melissa Clark recipe benefits from the addition of brandy, and you can even use canned squash in place of the pumpkin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanya Yanagihara
title: In Strange Times, Eerie Stories Confront the Unknown
description: Tales of otherworldly figures aren’t necessarily meant to frighten — they’re ways to explain the living’s unresolved matters of the heart.
content: Every traveler knows that some of the most moving and profound encounters she has in a foreign land aren’t with the living, but the dead. There’s something about having your equilibrium upset that makes the past seem closer, more accessible, and understanding that you’re walking atop the same ramparts, or down the same medina alleys, or over the same packed-earth streets as travelers from a century, two centuries, millennia ago, makes you feel both less consequential and, at the same time, less alone. Here I am, you think, one person of countless millions, and although my time here is brief, I too will have joined the others by leaving my footfall on this earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh, Mitch Smith and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: With cases soaring, Biden plans to name a virus task force.
description: Hours after President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. declared the coronavirus a top priority, the magnitude of his task became starkly clear on Sunday as the nation surpassed 10 million cases and sank deeper into the grip of what could become the worst chapter yet of the pandemic.
content: Hours after President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. declared the coronavirus a top priority, the magnitude of his task became starkly clear on Sunday as the nation surpassed 10 million cases and sank deeper into the grip of what could become the worst chapter yet of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden and Isabella Kwai
title: You’ve Got (Century-Old) Mail: Soldier’s Note Is Echo of World War I Era
description: The message with spidery writing, carrying details of German military drills, was found in eastern France in a capsule probably dropped by a carrier pigeon.
content: PARIS — It was an unusual object to spot in the flat grassy fields of eastern France: A small aluminum capsule found in the middle of nowhere near Ingersheim, a town in Alsace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Saying He Was a ‘Scapegoat,’ Jeff Luhnow Sues the Astros
description: In a $22 million lawsuit, Houston’s former general manager claims that the actual culprit of the team’s cheating scandal is still employed by the club.
content: Jeff Luhnow, the former general manager of the Houston Astros, is free to work again in Major League Baseball. His one-year suspension — punishment for the team’s sign-stealing scandal — expired at the end of the World Series, as did suspensions for the former Astros manager A.J. Hinch and the former bench coach Alex Cora.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and John Koblin
title: The historian Jon Meacham, who wrote of ‘the soul of America,’ has been working on Biden’s speeches.
description: Jon Meacham, the presidential historian and biographer, has been helping to craft President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s speeches, according to multiple sources involved, including helping to write the acceptance speech that Mr. Biden delivered Saturday night from Wilmington, Del.
content: Jon Meacham, the presidential historian and biographer, has been helping to craft President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s speeches, according to multiple sources involved, including helping to write the acceptance speech that Mr. Biden delivered Saturday night from Wilmington, Del.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Kamala Harris Makes California History
description: Monday: The senator is the first Democrat from the Golden State to win on a national presidential ticket.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: A Transition Without a Concession
description: Biden prepares for the White House as Trump drags his feet leaving: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Biden is moving ahead with his transition plans, but Trump still refuses to concede. Republicans aren’t sure how to handle it. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: What Will Trump’s Most Profound Legacy Be? Possibly Climate Damage
description: President-elect Biden can restore many of the 100-plus environmental regulations that President Trump rolled back, but much of the damage to the climate cannot be reversed.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will use the next four years to try to restore the environmental policies that his predecessor has methodically blown up, but the damage done by the greenhouse gas pollution unleashed by President Trump’s rollbacks may prove to be one of the most profound legacies of his single term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: Start a New Tradition With Your Thanksgiving Potatoes
description: For faster, more flavorful Thanksgiving potatoes, do as J. Kenji López-Alt does, and stir-fry them.
content: At the holidays, recipes that are simple on their own become more difficult when you try to juggle them all in a single kitchen. To make things less complicated, I’m taking a novel approach with my potatoes this year, one that requires only a bit of prep work, and a few minutes of attention at dinner time: I’m stir-frying them in my wok.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Buttermilk-Brined Turkey of Your Thanksgiving Dreams
description: Every November, people ask Samin Nosrat if her beloved roast chicken recipe works with turkey. She decided to find out.

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: In the Arctic, Reindeer Are Sustenance and a Sacred Presence
description: For the Indigenous communities who herd the animals, safeguarding dying culinary traditions isn’t merely about eating but about protecting a longstanding way of life.
content: IN NORTHERN SAMI, a language spoken in the uppermost reaches of Norway, Sweden and Finland, eallu is a herd, or more precisely, the herd — of reindeer, always, on whose lives the speakers depend. Between 400 and 500 words may be used to single out each animal within the herd, by coloring, girth, stance, stage of life, branching pattern of antlers, even temperament, from the truculent female who resists the rope (njirru) to the plodder whose hooves hardly leave the ground (slohtur) to the one that keeps its own counsel, hovering at the fringes (ravdaboazu). That this is poetic is incidental; it is knowledge first, essential to survive. Etymologically, “eallu” is kin, via the proto-Uralic root ela, to ealat, which encompasses both a pasture and the conditions that make it good for grazing, and to eallin: life, which the eallu and ealat make possible.
source.name: The New York Times
